name: Kepler-267
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-267 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-267 is a star with 0.45999999999999985 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.56 times its radius. It is located 870.84 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-267 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-267 b

Kepler-267 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 3.35 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-267.

The mass of Kepler-267 b is 4.98 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-267 b is 1.98 that of Earth. At 4.98 Earth masses, Kepler-267 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-267 c

Kepler-267 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 6.88 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-267.

The mass of Kepler-267 c is 5.90 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-267 c is 2.13 that of Earth. At 5.90 Earth masses, Kepler-267 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-267 d

Kepler-267 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.15 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 28.46 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-267.

The mass of Kepler-267 d is 6.92 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-267 d is 2.27 that of Earth. At 6.92 Earth masses, Kepler-267 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-267, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
